column20:
between re-opening HSM, perhaps even between completely logging
in again.  Therefor there is an architectural error, keys cannot
be stored stable in the zone!  This should change and we should
obtain the set of keys before starting to sign a zone, and do
away with them afterwards.  This ensures they are not used outside
of an hsm context.  This change is not feasable now.  We can
remove the HSM part of the keys effectively from the zone but we
cannot carry them around.  So for now make a cache of keys in
the hsm context.  This has major drawbacks, it is slower
and will leak memory as the HSM keys are not deallocated when
they are effectively no longer in use.  The latter will only
become severe when doing many rollbacks.
First simple implementation of the cache as a linked list.

first one preferrd)  With libbacktrace_full you get line numbers.  Using
libunwind will get a more reliable backtrace than the basic backtrace.
If even backtrace() is not available it will resort back to dladdr call.
The crashtest program showing how a backtrace is made (to be removed when
all tests pass).
ods_janitor_initialize is specific for OpenDNSSEC to prepare the right
threadclasses and installs the right signal handlers.  It should be
called with the full path to the program as soon as possible in the
OpenDNSSEC daemon applications.
remove the delegation to a start function which subsequently based on the
type delegates to a drugder or worker function.  This delegation was
not needed anymore since the janitor will call function returning void
rather than returning a void* and any signal masks are already
installed.
Use janitor_thread_create rather than calling pthreads directly.  The
janitor needs to perform a number of actions immediately after starting
the thread, and be able to register all threads being created.  This
ensures this always happens.
Rather than masking, blocking and catching signals explicitly, detaching
a thread, set attributes directly, the janitor uses threadclasses.
A threadclass encompases all these characteristics of a thread, allowing
these to be set-up beforehand, just like the normal pthread_attr_t.
Disadvantage is that you cannot change this afterwards, but that was not
used anyway.
removal of the disfunctional code that tried to emulate some functionality
when there was no pthreads available.  Pthreads is a prerequisite.
a thread number, thread name and thead type is now replaced by just the
name of the thread, which includes a name and number the same way.  The
type was only used for printing the name and only during startup to
call the right start function.  The latter is no longer needed, since
we already delegate to a function that returns NULL and already install
the signal handers and detach the thread when needed based on the
threadclass.
the thread identifier of type pthread_t is hidden by the janitor to
prevent accidental misuse of pthread calls that need intervention
by the janitor.  Therefor a few replacements

SIGHUP is the only valid signal to "signal" daemons of events,
therefor a janitor_thread_signal call that just calls pthread_kill
with SIGHUP is made.
pthreads_join is replaced by janitor_thread_join which also cleans up
the janitor specific datastructures and handlers.  Also the OpenDNSSEC
never used the return data, therefor it is removed.

column13: OPENDNSSEC-612 (part 1): rewrite of signer scheduling code
column20:
rewrite of signed scheduling code, containing loads of gotos, state
variables to remember interrupted and halted tasks, remembering which task
to do next, overriding tasks, etcetera.
Made a procedure where different tasks, with their callback functions are
registered.  This helps to keep the task type and task callback functions
(which are a one-to-one mapping) in sync.  It also hides the information
which static function is actually used to the code that wants to inject
a task, and does away with a boiler plate function for every task.
The signer code uses this now, the enforcer code not yet.
the callback function now may explicitly return SUCCESS, FAILURE, DEFER
(causing a back-off method to be used) or time for the next time to be
scheduled.  This allows you to distuigish from successfull execution
to permanent failure (rather than defer), and uses more symblolic and thus
readable return codes rather than "what does -1 mean".
Also allowed to schedule time is to use PROMPTLY or IMMEDIATELY.  Both
mean "now", but with higher precedence given to immediately.
when removing tasks, you can also use WHENEVER and WHATEVER to remove
a task scheduled disregarding at what time is is scheduled for, or
of which type of task.
removal of the single run ability of the signer!!!
some debug syslog messages are slightly different, as the module changed.
Make the testing code less dependent on this.
Introduce a nice debugging function janitor_backtrace() that prints
the current stack trace to the logging facility.
solve bug which causes the line number in a stack backtrace not to be
printed (locks.c).
enable the stack trace dumping in case of a segv by default.
rename some sched_ functions to schedule_ to clean up signer code.  Drop
some unused versions.

In this case only a regular roll would need to take place.  On the other hand if a change is made that requires a roll, the enforcer should take the most convervative values in a roll, so it may take a while.

column13: Add missing extern in multiple headers
column20:
All symbols declared in a header file must be marked as extern, otherwise the declaration acts as a definition and you end up with multiple symbols when attempting to link. This is required in order to build with GCC-10. See this related GCC ticket for details.
This was tested on Debian (unstable/experimental).

column13: replace USE_ED25519/USE_ED448 constants with cpp macros
column20:
Currently the autoconf input file hardcodes USE_ED25519 and USE_ED448 to 1, and actual use of Ed25519/Ed448 is gated on LDNS_REVISION checks. In ldns 1.8 this no longer works because the LDNS_SIGN_EDxxx constants are not provided unless ldns was built with support for them. i.e. without this or an alternative fix, opendnssec will not build at all on a system with ldns 1.8 that was not built with Ed support.
This PR removes the hardcoded autoconf USE_EDxxx=1 and replaces them with plain preprocessor macros of the same name. For ldns 1.7.x they do the same as before. For 1.8 they use the new LDNS_BUILD_CONFIG_USE_EDxxx macros provided by ldns.
Fixes building opendnssec on OpenBSD with 1.8 (libressl of course has some Ed support, but it doesn't provide the full API from newer openssl yet, so ldns doesn't enable it).
